rubric_items.passed_description:
The README is included with the project and has instructions for building/running the project.

If any additional libraries are needed to run the project, these are indicated with cross-platform installation instructions.

You can submit your writeup as markdown or pdf.
rubric_items.criteria: A README with instructions is included with the project

rubric_items.passed_description:
The README describes the project you have built. 

The README also indicates the file and class structure, along with the expected behavior or output of the program.
rubric_items.criteria: The README indicates which project is chosen.

rubric_items.passed_description: The README indicates which rubric points are addressed. The README also indicates where in the code (i.e. files and line numbers) that the rubric points are addressed.
rubric_items.criteria: The README includes information about each rubric point addressed.

sections.name: Compiling and Testing (All Rubric Points REQUIRED)

rubric_items.passed_description:
The project code must compile  and run without errors. 

We strongly recommend using `cmake` and `make`, as provided in the starter repos. If you choose another build system, the code must compile on any reviewer platform.
rubric_items.criteria: The submission must compile and run.

rubric_items.passed_description:
A variety of control structures are used in the project.

The project code is clearly organized into functions.
rubric_items.criteria: The project demonstrates an understanding of C++ functions and control structures.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project reads data from an external file or writes data to a file as part of the necessary operation of the program.
rubric_items.criteria: The project reads data from a file and process the data, or the program writes data to a file.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project accepts input from a user as part of the necessary operation of the program.
rubric_items.criteria: The project accepts user input and processes the input.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project code is organized into classes with class attributes to hold the data, and class methods to perform tasks.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses Object Oriented Programming techniques.

rubric_items.passed_description: All class data members are explicitly specified as public, protected, or private.
rubric_items.criteria: Classes use appropriate access specifiers for class members.

rubric_items.passed_description: All class members that are set to argument values are initialized through member initialization lists.
rubric_items.criteria: Class constructors utilize member initialization lists.

rubric_items.passed_description: All class member functions document their effects, either through function names, comments, or formal documentation. Member functions do not change program state in undocumented ways.
rubric_items.criteria: Classes abstract implementation details from their interfaces.

rubric_items.passed_description: Appropriate data and functions are grouped into classes. Member data that is subject to an invariant is hidden from the user. State is accessed via member functions.
rubric_items.criteria: Classes encapsulate behavior.

rubric_items.passed_description: Inheritance hierarchies are logical. Composition is used instead of inheritance when appropriate. Abstract classes are composed of pure virtual functions. Override functions are specified.
rubric_items.criteria: Classes follow an appropriate inheritance hierarchy.

rubric_items.passed_description: One function is overloaded with different signatures for the same function name.
rubric_items.criteria: Overloaded functions allow the same function to operate on different parameters.

rubric_items.passed_description: One member function in an inherited class overrides a virtual base class member function.
rubric_items.criteria: Derived class functions override virtual base class functions.

rubric_items.passed_description: One function is declared with a template that allows it to accept a generic parameter.
rubric_items.criteria: Templates generalize functions in the project.

rubric_items.passed_description: At least two variables are defined as references, or two functions use pass-by-reference in the project code.
rubric_items.criteria: The project makes use of references in function declarations.

rubric_items.passed_description: At least one class that uses unmanaged dynamically allocated memory, along with any class that otherwise needs to modify state upon the termination of an object, uses a destructor.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses destructors appropriately.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project follows the Resource Acquisition Is Initialization pattern where appropriate, by allocating objects at compile-time, initializing objects when they are declared, and utilizing scope to ensure their automatic destruction.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses scope / Resource Acquisition Is Initialization (RAII) where appropriate.

rubric_items.passed_description: For all classes, if any one of the copy constructor, copy assignment operator, move constructor, move assignment operator, and destructor are defined, then all of these functions are defined.
rubric_items.criteria: The project follows the Rule of 5.

rubric_items.passed_description: For classes with move constructors, the project returns objects of that class by value, and relies on the move constructor, instead of copying the object.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses move semantics to move data, instead of copying it, where possible.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project uses at least one smart pointer: `unique_ptr`, `shared_ptr`, or `weak_ptr`. The project does not use raw pointers.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses smart pointers instead of raw pointers.

rubric_items.passed_description: The project uses multiple threads in the execution.
rubric_items.criteria: The project uses multithreading.

rubric_items.passed_description: A promise and future is used to pass data from a worker thread to a parent thread in the project code.
rubric_items.criteria: A promise and future is used in the project.

rubric_items.passed_description: A mutex or lock (e.g. `std::lock_guard` or `std::unique_lock)  is used to protect data that is shared across multiple threads in the project code.
rubric_items.criteria: A mutex or lock is used in the project.

rubric_items.passed_description: A `std::condition_variable` is used in the project code to synchronize thread execution.
rubric_items.criteria: A condition variable is used in the project.
